One expects haji yu 1 I rakryān·. The expected preposition is absent also in the following entries in the list.
This is the expected reading (compare with Sobhamerta 4v6). The anusvāra is irregularly shaped.

What remains visible of the damaged akṣara assumed by Wibowo to be ra does not seem to be compatible with that reading, and a more convincing restitution is furnished by line 3.4, where we read patiḥ maṁharap· babak·.
Cf. Kinawe line 12 samgat laṇḍayan pu vudyaṅ.
One could also read karukh·, but karuk· is expected. Cf. Bimalasrama 10r3 saṁ karuk·.
Perhaps the scribe intended and wrote vilaṁ (cf. vilaṁ vanua in 1r11)?

Wibowo reads a punctuation sign after vitāna, but I cannot see it on the photo of the plate, which admittedly is a bit worn here. Its presence is possible, but not necessary; some contemporary inscriptions punctuate the text here in this formula, while others do not.
2341 (Linggasuntan face C, line 32) proposed to correct to babakan, but babaka is found in Anjuk Ladang back, line 14; in Paradah II, face C line 79; Kampak back, line 10.

See the correction dalam er proposed in , 23, 43). The same spelling is found in Linggasuntan face C, line 39 and Paradah II (back line 34), Anjuk Ladang back, line 19, and Rukam 2r18. On the other hand, dalamm er· is found in Paradah I (2B13). The form dalam air is found in Gilikan (first plate, v11).
Or should we consider that this is the same as the term encountered in 1.12 and edit paṅin-aṅain·?

div.p: Homage be to the six Vināyakas! Hail! Elapsed Śaka year 861, month of Bhadrapada, fifth tithi of the waning fortnight, Vās, Pahiṅ, Friday, lunar mansion Aśvinī, deity Aśvī, conjunction Viṣkambha. That was the time that the decree of the Great King, rakai Halu, dyah Siṇḍok Śrī Īśānavikrama, received by the rakryān minister of Halu, dyah Sahasra, descended to the officiant of Kanuruhan, pu Udā, instructing with regard to the varuk land at Ālasantan, district of Bavaṅ Mapapan, that it be made the freehold of or: that it be made into a freehold by the rakryān kabayān, mother of rakryān minister of Halu, dyah Sahasra.

Its total: 13 tampah, in addition to the housing-premises and orchards, the price for them being 12 kāṭi of gold. The headmen of Ālasantan together with the inhabitants of the village sold the land. Every headman received gold:
vinəkases
the elder Vantil, Pastī, Sukhamī, the teacher Dr̥vyak, Kaḍaṅayan, Suji, Rambay, Jikən, Lubhī market seller
Maṇḍarah gusti
Aṅkat scribes
Tambi, Bhr̥tyah, Bharalī, Duvəg, Baryuṅ, Tuṅgəṅ, Vulakan, Popoṅ spokesman
Mañciṅ foresters
Varakas, Kabat, Khyāti, Suraṅgaṇā, Telā, Puluh, Bhujī, Saṇḍak vakulan
Mandon maṇḍal
Lālaṅ akajar
Kumīs, Ḍampal, Kuhal, Capil varigas
Kālih Bakacak, Busta, Saṅlā tuha vərəh
Dayī, Cabil
Such was the total of the headmen receiving gold.

The purpose of the land being made a freehold was to become a paṅurumbigyan freehold of the rakryān kabayān. Its status would be independent. It should not be entered as before by the patihs, the vahutas, the headmen, and all types of collectors of royal revenues: various miśras, various types of vulu, paṅuraṅ, kriṅ, paḍam, manimpiki, paraṇakan, limus galuḥ, paṅaruhan, taji, vatu tajam, sukun, halu varak, rakadut, pinilai, kataṅgaran, tapa haji, air haji, malandaṅ, ləca, ləblab, kalaṅkaṅ, kutak, taṅkil, tr̥pan, salvīt, vatu palaṅ, pamaṇikan, sikpān, rumbān, tiṅkəs, viji kavaḥ, vilaṅ vanua, tuha dagaṅ, juru guśali, tuhān nambi, tuhān huñjaman, juru juḍi, juru jalir, miśra hino, vli hapū, vli vaduṅ, vli tambaṅ, vli pañjut, vli harəṅ, pabisar, palamak, pakaluṅkuṅ, urutan, dampulan, tpuṅ kavuṅ, suṅsuṅ paṅuraṅ, forest dwellers (pasuk alas), payuṅan, pāṅin-aṅin, sipad bilut, puluṅ paḍi, skar tahun, panrāṅan, panusuh, hopan, mahouts (pahaliman), eunuchs (kḍi) healesr (valyan), actors (vidu), sambal, sumbul, royal servants (hulun haji), pamr̥ṣi, sinaguha, the courtiers vatak i jro, etc., shall not enter into the paṅurumbigyan freehold of the varuk land at Ālasantan. Only the rakryān founder of the freehold herself shall have authority over all its royal revenues.

Likewise the payments for harms and compensations sukha-duḥkha, such as:

? tūtan
? ḍaṇḍa kuḍaṇḍa

?
etc.
The rakryān founder of the freehold shall be the beneficiary of all its royal revenues.

As for those who mañambul
paint black mañavriṅ
make muslin maṁlākha
dye red maṅapus

Only the rakryān founder of the freehold herself shall have authority over all its royal revenues.

Likewise the numbers of those who engage in trade while present there are restricted, that is those not subjected to the enjoyers of royal dues is four tradesman of the same trade per freehold. If they buy buffaloes, the share of buffaloes is 20 per tradesman; 40 cattle per tradesman; 80 sheep per tradesman; one flock/shelter of ducks per tradesman; silver-smiths, four masters; those who drive ox-carts, four yokes; drums, three places to play (make?) them; carpenters, two tradesman; goldsmiths, two smithies; coppersmiths, two smithies; ironsmiths, two smithies; cadar-clothmakers, eight cadar-clothmaking places. If their wares are carried with carrying-poles — such as cloth vendors, tinkers vendors of copper utensils, condiment sellers, fence makers, transporters of cotton, mengkudu, iron, copper, brass, tin, salt blocks, sesame, uncooked rice, sugar, safflower (seeds?) — all types of wares that are carred with poles: altogether there will be five carrying-pole loads per tradesman. Those who are in conformity with that will not be subjected to the enjoyers of royal dues, wherever those traders might go, whatever may be there origin. However, they should keep a document to that effect. If their trade is more than the limit imposed on them, they will be subjected in accordance with the surplus to the enjoyers of one royal share sa-uddhāra. It will not be exceeded.

After giving the gifts with cloth to all of them, the offerings for the Makudur were placed below the canopy. The one serving as priest poured water to purify the ‘heart’ for piercing and the kulumpaṅ stone. The Makudur arises bringing sembah to the holy ‘heart’ and sits below the canopy, having his feet as support (i.e. knelt), facing the holy ‘heart’, wearing as siṅhəl 1 set of cloth. The Vadihati follows. The Makudur begins to uyut, and cleaves the neck of a chicken, using the kulumpaṅ-stone as underlay, and bashes an egg on the sīma stone, prononouncing admonition and imprecation adressed to all those who are customarily admonished so that the holy freehold will be respected:

The term varuk is not well understood. varuk glosses a piece of ground (acquired in a part. way? bought?), while 13 tentatively suggested: Mungkin kata lmaḥ waruk menunjuk bagian yang masih hutan belukar.
The headword of each entry in the list (vinkas, apkan, gusti, etc.) is directly followed by a name, further names separated by median dots.

The word paṅurumbigyan is derived, with pa-...-an circumfix, from kurumbigi which seems to be an alternate of kurumbhāgi, a kind of iron tool (knife) (). The compound term sīma paṅurumbigyan is reminiscent of the much more common pattern sīma ka-...-an (sīma kajurugusalyan, sīma kavajvan, sīma kakaṭikan, etc.) seen in numerous Old Javanese inscriptions.
I adopt the interpretation of the term sukha-duḥkha itself, and of the meanings of the items in the list, from work in progress by Timothy Lubin.

First edited by Wibowo (). Re-edited here by Arlo Griffiths from photographs by Nigel Bullough. The rather numerous instances where Wibowo’s edition shows small errors of reading due to omission of a diacritic mark (macron or underdot) have been passed over in silence in the apparatus that accompanies the present edition, as have most variant readings that involve punctuation signs.
